summary: This is a sealed ex parte conference transcript from the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judge Colleen McMahon discusses procedural issues with an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the government's application to modify a protective order from a sealed civil libel case involving Ghislaine Maxwell, to allow the law firm Boies Schiller to comply with a grand jury subpoena in a human trafficking investigation.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Presiding judge in the ex parte conference, questioning the procedural posture of the government's application to modify a protective order related to the Maxwell case and expressing concerns about the protective order's validity.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Listed as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, but the conference is conducted with an unnamed Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA).

persons.name: Judge Sweet
persons.context: The deceased judge who originally entered the protective order in the sealed Maxwell libel case. Judge McMahon is now handling the matter and references his prior involvement and an unwritten opinion.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Named as a principal of the law firm Boies Schiller, which represented plaintiffs in the Maxwell libel case and is the recipient of the grand jury subpoena. Judge McMahon questions why his firm did not make its own motion for relief from the protective order.

persons.name: Judge Broderick
persons.context: Mentioned by Judge McMahon as having stated in the Chemical Bank case that the proper procedure is for a party subject to a protective order to move to be relieved from it.

persons.name: Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as the plaintiff in the underlying sealed civil libel action. The protective order was designed to protect her confidential information. Judge McMahon notes she would likely protest the government's application if she were aware of it.

connections.description: Judge Sweet presided over the sealed civil libel case in which Maxwell was the plaintiff and entered the protective order at issue.
Boies Schiller represented the plaintiffs in the libel case against Maxwell. They are in possession of discovery materials subject to the protective order.
The government has issued a grand jury subpoena to Boies Schiller and is applying to the court to modify the protective order so the firm can comply.
Judge McMahon inherited the procedural mess from the late Judge Sweet and is trying to understand the basis for his protective order.

events.title: Ex Parte Conference on Protective Order
events.description: Sealed court conference where Judge McMahon hears the government's application to modify a protective order to allow Boies Schiller to comply with a grand jury subpoena in a human trafficking investigation.

events.title: Second Circuit Review of Sealed Documents
events.description: Referenced event where the Second Circuit Court of Appeals is reviewing and appears poised to order the unsealing of many documents from the underlying Maxwell libel case, indicating potential reversal of Judge Sweet's sealing practices.

events.title: Death of Judge Sweet
events.description: Judge Sweet passed away, leaving unresolved the government's application regarding the protective order and creating procedural complications for Judge McMahon.

events.title: Government's All Writs Act Application
events.description: The government submitted an application under the All Writs Act to Judge Sweet nearly two months prior, seeking modification of the protective order to facilitate its grand jury investigation.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York, New York, N.Y.
keyFacts: The U.S. government is investigating allegations of human trafficking, and the grand jury has subpoenaed the law firm Boies Schiller for all discovery materials from a sealed civil libel case involving Ghislaine Maxwell.
A protective order from the sealed Maxwell case is blocking Boies Schiller from complying with the subpoena. The government is asking the court to modify that order.

Judge McMahon expresses deep procedural and substantive concerns, including the government's standing to bring the motion, the breadth of the subpoena, and the precarious legal footing of the original protective order, which the Second Circuit appears ready to overturn.

The judge indicates the protective order lacks a standard clause allowing disclosure to law enforcement, and the government argues any clause absolutely prohibiting such disclosure would be void as against public policy.
The entire proceeding is conducted ex parte and under seal, and Judge McMahon orders it to be assigned a proper miscellaneous docket number to ensure it is not 'off the radar screen.'
